channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Death Toll Rises to 21 in Missile Strikes Near Odesa
item.description: Ukrainians accused Russia of retaliation for driving Russian forces from Snake Island, a strategic blow, but the attack was of a piece with similar apparently random strikes on residential areas.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times

item.title: More Mexicans Are Migrating to the U.S. After a Decade-Long Drop
item.description: The death of at least 53 migrants in Texas, more than half of whom were from Mexico, is testing U.S. efforts to enlist Mexico in deterring migration.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Cristopher Rogel Blanquet for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yolanda Olivares, left, holding photos of her sons, Jair and Yovani Valencia Olivares, duing a march on Thursday in southern Mexico. The two brothers are missing and may have been among the migrants found in an abandoned trailer in Texas.

item.title: Hong Kong’s Transformation Since Handover
item.description: In the 25 years since the handover to China, life on Queen’s Road, the first thoroughfare built by the British after they seized the territory, has been transformed.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Sergey Ponomarev

item.title: ‘Mango Man’ Is the Fruit’s Foremost Poet, Philosopher, Fan and Scientist
item.description: With 300 types of mangos to his horticultural credit, Kaleem Ullah Khan is quick to tell anyone in India and beyond about the infinite potential of the fruit and its tree, including as medicine.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kaleem Ullah Khan in front of the 120-year-old tree onto which he has grafted over 300 varieties of mangoes, at his tree nursery in Malihabad, India, in April.

item.title: ‘Long Live the Theater’: Mariupol’s Drama Company to Perform Again
item.description: Thirteen members of the Mariupol Drama Theater have reconvened in western Ukraine where they are rehearsing a new play about a Ukrainian dissident who died in a Russian prison camp in the 1980s.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Actors from Mariupol’s Academic Regional Drama Theater rehearsing for a new play in Uzhhorod, in western Ukraine, this month.

item.title: Venice Will Require Tourists to Register and Pay Entry Fee
item.description: City officials are introducing a new fee to visit Venice and its islands, a move, they hope, will limit tourists.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A scenic view of the grand canal from the Rialto bridge, in Venice, Italy.

item.title: Tunisia’s President, Kais Saied, Proposes New Constitution
item.description: The proposal, which will be put to a national referendum on July 25, would enshrine the significant steps he has taken over the past year to dismantle the North African nation’s young democracy.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:credit: Fethi Belaid/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Kais Saied of Tunisia suspended Parliament and fired his prime minister almost a year ago amid political paralysis and economic convulsions.

item.title: Why Is There So Much Turmoil in Eastern Congo?
item.description: More than 120 militia groups are wreaking terror in the Democratic Republic of Congo, which now accuses neighboring Rwanda of backing one particularly violent group.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Arlette Bashizi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Congolese army tank heads towards the front line in eastern Congo in May.

item.title: What We Know About Brittney Griner’s Detention in Russia
item.description: The W.N.B.A. star was stopped at an airport outside Moscow and accused of carrying hashish oil in her luggage. She is expected to remain in custody through her trial.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Sergio Perez/Reuters
item.media:description: Brittney Griner of the United States during the 2020 Tokyo Olympics women’s basketball game against France in Saitama, Japan, in August.

item.title: Labeled a ‘Challenge’ by NATO, China Signals Its Own Hard-Line Worldview
item.description: The alliance’s forceful declaration in its mission statement reinforced Beijing’s belief that hostile powers are bent on hobbling the country’s ascent.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin and Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden joining NATO leaders for a group photo on Wednesday at the NATO summit in Madrid.

item.title: Xi Jinping Tells a Muted Hong Kong That Political Power Is for Patriots
item.description: The Chinese leader’s first visit to the former British colony since a sweeping crackdown was a declaration of victory, an assertion of power and a warning to critics.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy and Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Selim Chtayti
item.media:description: Xi Jinping spoke Friday after the swearing-in of Hong Kong’s new government. “At this moment, Hong Kong is entering a new stage — moving from the transition from chaos to governance,” he said.

item.title: Denmark’s Leader Apologizes for Botched Pandemic Mink Cull
item.description: The comments by Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen came after a report called the government’s decision in 2020 to kill some 17 million mink over coronavirus fears illegal.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola, Isabella Kwai and Jasmina Nielsen
item.media:credit: Morten Stricker/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A site near Holstebro, Denmark, where the government was disposing of dead mink in November 2020.

item.title: Yair Lapid, Israel’s New Prime Minister, Played the Long Game to Power
item.description: Once mocked for his inexperience and perceived arrogance, Israel’s caretaker premier taught voters a lesson in political maturity and humility.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yair Lapid, at the Blue and White party office in Tel Aviv in 2019. He has matured in his decade in Israeli politics, analysts say.

item.title: Why Does Israel Have So Many Elections?
item.description: Israelis are heading back to the polls for the fifth time in under four years.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Maya Alleruzzo/Associated Press
item.media:description: Naftali Bennett, left, the prime minister at the time, with his foreign minister, Yair Lapid, at Israel’s Parliament, in Jerusalem in June.

item.title: Landslide in India Buries Dozens, Killing at Least 18
item.description: Days of heavy rain had loosened the soil. India and neighboring Bangladesh have had record rainfall and severe flooding in the past two months.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:credit: National Disaster Response Force/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The scene in the Noney District of Manipur, India, on Friday, after a large landslide struck near a railway construction site.

item.title: Ill-Prepared for Combat, Volunteers Die in Battles Far From Home
item.description: Many of the fighters for Ukraine’s western territorial defense units were assigned benign tasks away from the fighting when they first joined. Then they were called to the front to fight.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and The New York Times
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gravediggers cover the grave of Yurii Brukhal during his funeral in Lviv.

item.title: Iran Earthquake Kills at Least 5, State Media Says
item.description: Iran’s state news agency said the quake, which did extensive damage to a village, was followed by two more.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:credit: Ali Haider/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Tremors from an earthquake that hit southern Iran early Saturday were felt in Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates, where people gathered outside their residential building.

item.title: At Comedy Shows in Lviv, Crowds Look for Humor Amid a Deadly War
item.description: At the Cultural Defense shows in Lviv, comedians and audiences look for humor amid a deadly conflict. Don’t mind the air raid alarms.
item.dc:creator: David Segal
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patrons pay about $13 apiece to watch the comics at a Cultural Defense show being performed at the Cult Comedy Hall, a club in downtown Lviv.

item.title: Biden Administration Offers an Offshore Drilling Plan. Likely Backers: Very Few.
item.description: The five-year plan for America’s coastal waters, required by law, risks angering both the fossil fuel industry and environmentalists.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Chris Carlson/Associated Press
item.media:description: Offshore drilling platforms near Huntington Beach, Calif.

item.title: Brittney Griner, Women’s Basketball Star, Goes on Trial in Russia
item.description: The American basketball star Brittney Griner has endured months in a Russian prison and the threat of years more, a wartime bargaining chip between Moscow and Washington.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Kirill Kudryavtsev/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Brittney Griner arriving at court on Friday.

item.title: Did the ‘Freedom Convoy’ Change the Meaning of Canada’s Flag?
item.description: On Canada Day, some citizens were wary of raising the national flag, now also associated with weeks of protests against pandemic mandates.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Ian Austen/The New York Times
item.media:description: Some Canadians fear that the flag has become a symbol of protest rather than a symbol of the nation.

item.title: From the Early Morning Sky, Shards of Hot Metal
item.description: Ukrainians reacted in fury to a Russian missile strike near Odesa, the latest in a string of attacks on civilian targets.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times

item.title: California Requires Plastics Makers to Foot the Bill for Recycling
item.description: The landmark legislation also restricts single-use plastics. Because California’s economy is so big, experts say, the law could have far-reaching effects.
item.dc:creator: Winston Choi-Schagrin
item.media:credit: Rich Pedroncelli/Associated Press
item.media:description: The California law is the fourth of its kind in the U.S., but experts say it’s the most significant.

item.title: With Climate Agenda Stalled at Home, Biden Still Hopes to Lead Abroad
item.description: The United States has demonstrated international leadership on climate change in the past, but recent setbacks are presenting new challenges for President Biden.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden addressed NATO nations at a summit in Madrid, Spain, on Thursday, hours before the U.S. Supreme Court ruled on a climate case.

item.title: Will There Be Enough Monkeypox Vaccine?
item.description: A factory making Jynneos, the safest vaccine, has been closed since August, threatening global supplies as the virus spreads.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Gavino Garay/Reuters
item.media:description: A patient received the Jynneos vaccine in a clinic in Washington on Tuesday. Some experts are concerned that the demand for monkeypox vaccine will soon exceed the global supply.

item.title: Benin Bronzes Returned to Nigeria from Germany
item.description: Two of the renowned artifacts were given back to Nigeria on Friday, and Germany intends to give the African country ownership of some 1,100 more.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: New Zealand Designates Proud Boys a Terrorist Group
item.description: The far-right Proud Boys are not known to operate in the country, but the designation makes it illegal for New Zealanders to support them.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Mark Mitchell/NZME, via Associated Press
item.media:description: New Zealand’s minister of police, Chris Hipkins, discussed the Proud Boys and the Base on Thursday in Wellington. “These are white supremacist terrorist groups,” he said.

item.title: Tropical Storm Bonnie Makes Landfall in Nicaragua
item.description: Bonnie lashed Nicaragua and Costa Rica late Friday after becoming the second named storm of this year’s Atlantic hurricane season.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Oswaldo Rivas/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: People at a temporary shelter in Bluefields, Nicaragua. before Tropical Storm Bonnie made landffall on Friday.

item.title: The Kremlin rejects the suggestion that Griner’s case is politically motivated.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Kirill Kudryavtsev/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: A Look Inside the Lockup Where Brittney Griner Has Been Held
item.description: At least one other well-known foreigner has spent time there: Naama Issachar, the Israeli-American arrested in April 2019 when the Russian police said they had found marijuana in her luggage.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Kirill Kudryavtsev/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Naama Issachar at a court hearing in Moscow in 2019.

item.title: The Court vs. the Climate
item.description: The Supreme Court seems unconcerned with climate change.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coal-fired power plant in Thompsons, Tex.

item.title: As Federal Climate-Fighting Tools Are Taken Away, Cities and States Step Up
item.description: Across the country, local governments are accelerating their efforts to cut greenhouse gas emissions, in some cases bridging partisan divides. Their role will become increasingly important.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Ryan David Brown for The New York Times
item.media:description: A wind farm run by Xcel Energy outside of Peetz, Colo. Xcel has pledged to reduce emissions 80 percent by 2030.

item.title: What to Know About Flight Delays and Cancellations This Summer
item.description: Going into the Fourth of July weekend, with nearly 13 million people expected to fly on U.S. carriers, we look at the numbers behind the delays and cancellations and see what lessons can be learned.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy
item.media:credit: Julia Nikhinson/Associated Press
item.media:description: Many airline passengers, like those waiting to go through security at John F. Kennedy International Airport recently, are experiencing long lines this summer, as the number of passengers has increased and the system struggles to accommodate them.

item.title: Pictures of Brittney Griner in Custody Offer Few Clues to Her Well-Being
item.description: Images of the W.N.B.A. star released since her arrest in an airport near Moscow on Feb. 17 have been scrutinized for clues about her mental and physical health.
item.dc:creator: Maham Javaid
item.media:credit: Kirill Kudryavtsev/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, the star of the Phoenix Mercury, arrived for a hearing on drug possession charges on Monday in a courthouse outside Moscow.

item.title: Russia hints at linking Griner’s case to Viktor Bout, a Russian known as the ‘Merchant of Death.’
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: U.S. Department of Justice, via Reuters
item.media:description: Viktor Bout, center, was arrested in 2008 and later sentenced to 25 years in prison. The Kremlin appears interested in a potential deal with the Biden administration to free the arms dealer.

item.title: Climate Protesters in Australia Face Harsh New Penalties
item.description: As of April, people in New South Wales who disrupt business activities can face up to two years in prison. Some climate activists say this law is aimed at them.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Steven Saphore/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Climate protesters from Blockade Australia in Sydney on Tuesday.

item.title: North Korea Suggests ‘Alien Things’ From South Brought Covid
item.description: Airborne propaganda leaflets sent by activists across the border have long angered the regime, which pointed to them as the likely culprit in the country’s recent outbreak.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A North Korean state media photograph showing workers disinfecting a shopping area in Pyongyang, the capital. The North says its first Covid outbreak began in April.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A major climate-related court ruling.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside the Supreme Court after the ruling yesterday.

item.title: Missile Strikes on Ukraine Kill at Least 21 Near Odesa
item.description: The strikes hit a residential tower and a recreational center in a coastal town southwest of the Black Sea port city of Odesa.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Wearing a Piece of History’: Vintage Clothing Stores Find a Growing Market
item.description: The demand for repurposed clothes is rising in Australia, store owners say, as shoppers look for sustainability and history over fast fashion.
item.dc:creator: Manan Luthra
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Newtown, a suburb of Sydney known for its quirky retail outlets and abundance of thrift stores.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: A Major U.S. Climate Ruling
item.description: Plus Xi Jinping visits Hong Kong and Ukraine takes back Snake Island.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. Supreme Court is seen in Washington, D.C. on Thursday.

item.title: Biden Vows to Back Ukraine ‘as Long as It Takes’ Despite Economic Toll
item.description: NATO leaders concluded a summit with new commitments to a united front against Russian aggression, but they face the challenge of persuading their own people that it’s worth the cost.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger, Jim Tankersley, Michael D. Shear and Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden during a news conference on Thursday at the conclusion of the NATO summit in Madrid.

item.title: Belgian Court Finds 10 Guilty Over Ties to 2015 Paris Attacks
item.description: The convictions followed the end of a giant trial in the French capital over the same massacre, in which 130 people were killed.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Constant Méheut
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: John Thys/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Belgian police standing guard in the Molenbeek district in Brussels, in Ma rch 2016.The neighborhood was home to key members of the terrorist network that plotted the Paris attacks of 2015.

item.title: Court Decision Leaves Biden With Few Tools to Combat Climate Change
item.description: A Supreme Court ruling, combined with an energy crunch and intraparty politics, makes it nearly impossible for President Biden to achieve his climate goals.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden met with governors, labor leaders, and private companies last week to discuss a federal and state partnership to develop more offshore wind energy.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Bankrolls a Challenge to the PGA
item.description: Saudi Arabia is investing in sporting events, like an upstart golf tour, as part of a yearslong drive to turn the country into a hot spot for business and tourism and to blunt criticism of its human rights record.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Ross Kinnaird/Getty Images
item.media:description: Phil Mickelson putting at a tournament in Saudi Arabia in 2020. He’s now one of the stars of the Saudi-backed LIV Golf circuit.

item.title: Biden Endorses Ending Filibuster to Codify Abortion Rights
item.description: The president called the Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe v. Wade “destabilizing’’ and said Congress needed to act to codify it into law.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Jim Tankersley
item.category: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden speaking Thursday during a news conference at the conclusion of the NATO summit in Madrid.

item.title: To Save Its Honey Industry, Australia Is Killing Bees by the Millions
item.description: Australia is the only major honey-producing country that has so far managed to contain the spread of a mite fatal to bees. That distinction is now in peril.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:credit: Lisa Maree Williams/Getty Images
item.media:description: A beekeeper inspecting hives in Bowral, New South Wales, last year.

item.title: Missing From Biden’s Europe Trip: An Endgame for War and Cheaper Gas
item.description: The G7 and NATO meetings this week underscored the pressure on Western leaders caused by soaring energy costs resulting from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden is already feeling political heat from his swift response to the Ukraine invasion, though few of his opponents in the United States are explicitly framing it that way.

item.title: Marcos Becomes President in the Philippines
item.description: The son of the former dictator used his inauguration speech to discuss the economy and the need to heal a deeply divided country after a polarizing election.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez and Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Ezra Acayan/Getty Images
item.media:description: Ferdinand Marcos Jr. taking the oath of office as he was sworn in as president of the Philippines at the National Museum of Fine Arts in Manila on Thursday.

item.title: A Powerful Court
item.description: In other advanced democracies, the courts are more restrained.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court’s structure allows for few checks on the justices’ power.

item.title: An Instagram hot spot becomes a display of loyalty to the mainland.
item.description: Hundreds of crimson Chinese flags appeared on the white balconies on two 28-story buildings in a soaring residential complex.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Kin Cheung/Associated Press
item.media:description: Chinese and Hong Kong flags hung from a residential building in Hong Kong to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the city’s handover to China.

item.title: Russian Forces Withdraw From Snake Island, a Setback for Moscow
item.description: The retreat came after sustained Ukrainian attacks, including with newly arrived Western weapons, made it impossible for Russian forces to hold the island.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko

item.title: Xi Jinping, China’s Leader, Visits Hong Kong, Cautiously
item.description: Before Xi Jinping’s tightly controlled appearance, Hong Kong sent officials, diplomats and others to hotels for days of isolation and Covid tests.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Zixu Wang and Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Selim Chtayti
item.media:description: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, arrived in Hong Kong on Thursday for celebrations marking the 25th anniversary of the city’s handover from Britain.

item.title: How Vitaliy Kim Became a Symbol of Ukraine’s Resistance
item.description: Applying the lessons of taekwondo, the regional military leader has rallied the embattled southern city of Mykolaiv.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vitaliy Kim has worked to puncture the legend of Russia’s might. “It was important to convey that the enemy was not as scary as it seemed, and to tell the world that we are here, that we exist,” he said.

item.title: In Athens Creativity in Art, Food and More Rises
item.description: The Greek capital has added impressive arts venues, daring restaurants and a blossoming hotel scene to its well-known Classical draws.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:credit: Maria Mavropoulou for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the heart of the city near Greece’s Parliament, the Athens Capital hotel has an extensive roof deck.

item.title: Day Care Centers Brace for Effects of Younger Children’s Covid Vaccinations
item.description: Federal action to make children older than 6 months eligible for vaccines not only affects parents but also day care centers, which have struggled throughout the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan and Christine Chung
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Johanna Villa, a preschool teacher, reading with her class at Seward Child Care Center in Minneapolis in February.

item.title: Israel’s Parliament Dissolves, Paving Way for Election in November
item.description: The decision brought down the coalition government and installed Yair Lapid, a centrist, as interim prime minister. Exhausted and exasperated Israelis will be asked to vote again in November.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Menahem Kahana/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Yair Lapid shaking hands with Naftali Bennett, front right, the departing prime minister, after the vote to dissolve Parliament on Thursday.

item.title: Xi visits Hong Kong amid high security and inside a Covid bubble.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Zixu Wang and Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Selim Chtayti
item.media:description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, hailed Hong Kong, a city transformed by Beijing’s crackdown on dissent, as “reborn from the ashes.”

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: A prisoner exchange in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: More than 2,500 Ukrainian soldiers surrendered to Russian forces in mid-May after fighting in Mariupol, Ukraine, from their base in the bunkers of the Azovstal steel plant for months.

item.title: Patient and Confident, Putin Shifts Out of Wartime Crisis Mode
item.description: Cloistered and spouting grievances at the start of the war on Ukraine, the Russian leader now appears publicly, projecting the aura of a calm, paternalistic leader shielding his people from the dangers of the world.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin of Russia arriving in Ashgabat, the capital of Turkmenistan, on Wednesday to attend the Caspian Summit.

item.title: Fauci, Recovering From ‘Rebound’ of Covid, Praises Paxlovid
item.description: Dr. Anthony Fauci, President Biden’s top pandemic adviser, sought to discourage doubts about the antiviral drug Paxlovid following what appeared to be a “rebound” of Covid-19 after taking the pills.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’m 81 years old, I was at risk for hospitalization and I didn’t even come close to being sick enough to be hospitalized,” Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, pictured earlier this month, said on Wednesday.
